image.altText: Keir Starmer giving a press conference in Downing Street with the British flag behind him.

props.synopsis: British PM Keir Starmer says his country will recognise a Palestinian state as early as September, unless Israel agrees to a ceasefire and a two-state solution.

title.children: UK to recognise Palestine unless Israel 'ends appalling Gaza situation'

image.altText: Palestinians wait to receive food from a charity kitchen

props.synopsis: The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification — a global initiative that assesses the extent of hunger suffered by a population — says the worst-case scenario of famine is currently playing out in the Gaza Strip.

title.children: Israel accuses Albanese of telling 'a lie' as report details evidence of starvation in Gaza

image.altText: Nine parachutes are seen floating through the sky attached to little boxes, next to a plane.

props.synopsis: Food has been airdropped in Gaza and "humanitarian corridors" have been set up to make it easier to distribute aid throughout the strip. But aid officials and Palestinians question whether it's enough.

title.children: 'We want our share': Gazans say they're struggling to reach airdropped aid

image.altText: Shipping containers stacked on a large boat, machinery lifting one of the metal containers

props.synopsis: The agency says "persistent uncertainties" around trade continue to dog the global economy, with US firms rushing to import goods before Donald Trump's August 1 trade deal deadline.

title.children: IMF upgrades Australian growth forecasts, despite tariffs uncertainty

props.synopsis: Under Donald Trump's tariff program, Australia appeared to be one of America's least badly treated friends. But, without a new deal, the president's latest idea would change that.

title.children: Australia may no longer be Trump's least badly treated friend

image.altText: A smartphone with the YouTube logo, with the website in the background behind it.

props.synopsis: Children and teenagers will be barred from logging into YouTube under the incoming social media ban for under 16s after the government reversed its plan to grant the video-sharing site an exemption.

title.children: YouTube won't be spared from social media ban for under 16s

image.altText: ny shooting

props.synopsis: New York police investigators believe Shane Tamura was trying to get to the NFL headquarters after shooting several people but accidentally entered the wrong elevator, the city's Mayor Eric Adams says.

title.children: Gunman in fatal New York shooting was targeting NFL office, mayor says

image.altText: A soldier stands near a blue tent with a dense pine forest and snow-topped mountains in the distance behind him

props.synopsis: India's home minister has told parliament the three men killed were Pakistanis.

title.children: Gunmen involved in shooting attack in India-administered Kashmir killed

image.altText: Several police seen at a protest rally. There are flags and several uniformed officers.

props.synopsis: The Palestine Action Group informed police of its intention to hold a March for Humanity on Sunday and said using the landmark would send a "powerful message" over concerns about mass starvation in Gaza.

title.children: Police block pro-Palestinian protesters' bid for Sydney Harbour Bridge march

image.altText: A  blue and white Novo Nordisk logo sign alongside a multi-storey white office building and green tree shrubbery

props.synopsis: The announcement came amid a slump in the company's share price and investor concerns about its experimental drug pipeline and ability to navigate challenges in the US market.

title.children: Novo Nordisk names new CEO amid concerns over Wegovy, Ozempic sales

image.altText: A girl in her 20s with green eyes looks straight at the camera wearings timber Aboriginal designed earrings

props.synopsis: With more than 600 Indigenous deaths in custody since the royal commission, First Nations families say the staggering toll is Australia's shame.

title.children: Apryl's mother fell asleep on a train, then died alone in a police cell

image.altText: Police stand around a suburban park chatting

props.synopsis: A teenage boy charged with killing a Perth woman while riding an allegedly unlicensed high-powered electric motorbike is charged with two further offences relating to the incident.

title.children: Teen accused of electric motorbike death hit with more charges

image.altText: SBS newsreader Mary Kostakidis

props.synopsis: A legal row between a former SBS television newsreader and a prominent Israeli Australian over tweets during the Israel–Gaza war has been described by one camp as a case of free speech, and the other as a case of hate speech.

title.children: Former SBS newsreader's social media posts trigger lawsuit

image.altText: Thai military officers in green camouflage clothing standing with their arms raised on a dirt road in front of armoured vehicles

props.synopsis: Displaced residents on Cambodia's north-western border with Thailand say they are hesitant to return home, a day after the nations agreed to an immediate ceasefire to end days of intense fighting.

title.children: Refugees fear going home amid concerns Thai-Cambodia ceasefire may not hold

image.altText: A firefighter shoots water through a doorway as he stands in a demolished hallway

props.synopsis: Russian glide bombs and missiles strike a Ukrainian prison and a medical facility, with US President Donald Trump threatening to punish Russia unless the attacks stop.

title.children: Ukraine calls deadly Russian strike on prison 'another war crime'

image.altText: Two hailstones sitting in the palm of a hand.

props.synopsis: The frequency of "giant" hail and the number of hail days in a season could increase substantially for multiple Australian cities as the climate warms, a new study has found.

title.children: The Australian cities bracing for more giant hail as climate warms

image.altText: A woman with straight purple bob hair-cut, wearing a white jacket and colourful blouse. Black vignette.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's minister for the prevention of domestic violence claims more than two-thirds of the coroner's inquest recommendations are "already in place".

title.children: NT government slams coroner over landmark DV report

image.altText: Primary school kids carrying backpacks on a rainy winter day.

props.synopsis: Teachers are preparing to hold a 24-hour strike next Wednesday as pay negotiations with the state government hit a stalemate.

title.children: Queensland teachers to strike for first time in 16 years as union seeks 'fair' pay

image.altText: A rocky landscape overlooks the ocean. There are around a dozen people wearing yellow uniforms unpacking truck

props.synopsis: A community-led call to remove rock lobster pots from a popular surf beach near Streaky Bay following two fatal shark attacks draws criticism from fishers who say there's "no scientific backing".

title.children: Rock lobster pots removed from surf beach following fatal shark attacks

image.altText: A young woman in a suit, smiling.

props.synopsis: Councillor Brooke Patterson apologises for code of conduct breaches but defends some of her actions, after an independent investigation finds she caused "distress" and created a "volatile environment" for senior staff.

title.children: Gold Coast councillor found to have breached code of conduct again

image.altText: Aerial of sheep wandering among the solar panels at Numurkah solar farm

props.synopsis: The approval of a solar farm in just 30 business days is an example of how the renewables rollout could be sped up if Australia's ageing environment laws were rewritten, the government says.

title.children: Solar farm approved in weeks shows how renewables rollout could speed up

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

props.synopsis: One of Australia's largest employers axes 45 jobs in its customer call centres after rolling out an artificial intelligence chatbot to deal with customer inquiries.

title.children: CBA replaces dozens of call centre jobs with AI chatbot

image.altText: A man in an NT Corrections uniform, holding a mesh spit hood.

props.synopsis: The NT government is reinstating the use of spit hoods in youth detention, eight years after the practice was banned. Why are spit hoods controversial and what are the laws across Australia?

title.children: What is a spit hood and why do police and prison guards use them?

image.altText: A torch pointed at a white patch.

props.synopsis: The ABC's Foreign Correspondent travels to cartel country in Mexico to see if the government's crackdown on drug cartels is working.

title.children: The 'astounding' secret police discovered under a Mexican cartel town

image.altText: Ross Garnaut

props.synopsis: The father of emissions trading in Australia has warned the nation is "on a path to comprehensive failure" without the urgent reintroduction of a carbon price.

title.children: Australia can 'spend a fortune to buy failure' or reintroduce a carbon price

image.altText: People working in an abattoir

props.synopsis: Legal counsel for a southern NSW abattoir has been accused of failing to accept full blame for its own failures that led to a worker losing a foot in a meat auger.

title.children: Abattoir reprimands worker months after he loses foot in auger

image.altText: a vehicle running over a crocodile at a river crossing

props.synopsis: A video of a large crocodile becoming stuck underneath a ute at a notorious river crossing in the Northern Territory has gone viral online.

title.children: Video shows crocodile stuck under ute as it crosses NT river

image.altText: Ellie Blackburn speaks while standing near a football and the AFLW premiership cup

props.synopsis: Ahead of its 10th season, amid stagnating crowds and ratings, AFL chief executive Andrew Dillon says the AFLW remains an investment "absolutely worth making".

title.children: AFLW remains 'investment worth making' despite concerns, Dillon says

image.altText: exterior of building with trees in foreground

props.synopsis: Initial reports suggest the young child sustained minor injuries after allegedly being struck with a mop.

title.children: Police investigate alleged assault on boy in Cairns childcare centre

image.altText: Joan Anderson hula hooping

props.synopsis: Joan Anderson, who spotted a new fad on a trip back to Australia and brought the hula hoop to the attention of a US toy company, dies aged 101.

title.children: Australian woman behind worldwide hula hoop sensation dies age 101

image.altText: Workers

props.synopsis: Job mobility is down, retrenchment is up and more than a million Australians are ready to start working immediately, the Australian Bureau of Statistics says.

title.children: More than a million unemployed Australians are job ready: ABS

image.altText: Emergency authorities attend to residents in rescue boats floating on floodwaters.

props.synopsis: At least 30 people have been killed after torrential downpours hit the Chinese capital, damaging roads, bringing down power poles and uprooting trees.

title.children: Heavy rains and floods kill 30 in Beijing

image.altText: A light-coloured single-storey building with green lawn, a driveway and metal gates in front.

props.synopsis: A Queensland childcare worker has been charged with torturing and repeatedly assaulting a one-year-old baby boy.

title.children: Educator charged with torturing baby boy in childcare centre

image.altText: A glass door with the Ramsay Psychology words and logo on it.

props.synopsis: Face-to-face mental health support saved Kate's life, now her health care provider wants her to move to telehealth instead.

title.children: Clients 'disgusted and appalled' by Ramsay psychology clinic shutdowns

image.altText: Lili Greer as a child hugging her mum Tina

props.synopsis: While Lili says her experience with violence and loss will have lifelong impacts, advocating for change has been part of her healing.

title.children: Lili's mum was murdered by her boyfriend. She is advocating for change
